title: In-line inflation eases rate cut pressure
text:
The most significant price rises this quarter were international holiday, travel and accommodation up 6.1 per cent, tobacco up 3.4 per cent and child care surprising with a 2.5 per cent increase.

The most significant price falls this quarter were automotive fuel down 2 per cent, fruit down 3.1 per cent and vegetables down 2.5 per cent.

As expected electricity prices also fell, down 1.6 per cent.

"The introduction of the Default Market Offer and Victorian Default Offer to replace standing offers in the eastern capital cities contributed to the fall," Australian Bureau of Statistics chief economist Bruce Hockman said.

Energy Minister Angus Taylor said on Wednesday that the figures pointed to government policy working.

"The latest CPI figures have come out and for the third quarter in a row we have seen reductions in electricity prices," Mr Taylor said.

"This is extremely good news for Australian families, households, small businesses and heavy industry. This is the turn around we wanted to see. We are now seeing it."

The ABS's household category for inflation saw its lowest September quarter rise since 1998 due to subdued rises in utilities up 0.7 per cent and rents up only 0.1 per cent. New dwelling purchases by owner-occupiers fell 0.2 per cent in the quarter.

"Weakness in housing related costs has played a large role in this weaker number," BIS Oxford Economics senior economist Sean Langcake said, "While established house prices have recovered of late, it is the rental market and construction sector that matter for CPI inflation."

"Price pressures are weak in these areas, and given the outlook for residential construction, this will likely persist. Further, inflation in utilities prices remains weak."

EY economists Jo Masters noted that in annual terms, rental inflation is now stuck at a record low of 0.4 per cent year on year for the past three quarters.

"Its unlikely to accelerate any time soon given the amount of supply coming on the market in Melbourne and Sydney," Ms Masters said.

The cost of building a home not including land – fell by 0.1 per cent in the quarter and have now fallen in annual terms for the first time since the series began in 1999.

The September quarter number is the 15th consecutive quarter of below-target inflation for the Reserve Bank.

Although the Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe said on Tuesday night that the focus for the central bank has been for inflation "very much on the medium term – hence ‘on average’ and ‘over time’," he has still implied that the inflation rate is a key guide to interest rate decisions.

"It is reasonable to expect that an extended period of low interest rates will be required in Australia to reach full employment and achieve the inflation target," Dr Lowe has said.

BIS Oxford Economics's Mr Langcake said he expected rates will remain on hold through the rest of the year, but that a further easing is likely in early 2020 if unemployment did not move lower.
description: Inflation was 0.5 per cent in the third quarter, in line with what economists expected, easing pressure on the Reserve Bank for another interest rate cut this year.
